body: Turns out this one is a duplicate of https://github.com/mcroydon/druid/commit/ae44e3ecfb0b9cf6bb7fdc0aaa488f32963c932d. I vote for taking @mcroydon's instead.
+1. However, 6a9d86e does not fix build.sh for me with java version 1.7.0_06-ea.

A start page exists at 

https://github.com/metamx/druid/wiki/Cluster-setup

RandomEtc. it actually does log it, but at debug level instead of info.  In a production setting, it's actually not uncommon to have a flurry of late events (if a server goes down for some time and then comes back up and pushes everything it has queued up, for example), so logging it on every occurrence actually wouldn't be great.

We should perhaps look at turning debug logging on for the relevant classes for the demos so that it's easier to see there though.  If we had done that, do you think it would've helped you out?

Also, the system maintains a count of the number of messages that it dropped, which it emits every minute (with the demo configurations, this is emitted to the logs at debug level).
Created Querying docs @ https://github.com/metamx/druid/wiki/Querying
What error do you get?  Would be nice if it built.

It would probably have helped, yes. But if debug logging is extremely chatty then perhaps not. It may just be necessary learning curve at the moment, and it will go away when there are examples that can correctly import historical data.
@octavore may have some feedback for you. It was a fresh VM and there may have been issues with the maven version, we're not sure.

I got it to build as follows on Ubuntu 12.04, by installing OpenJDK7 and pointing my JAVA_HOME to it:

sudo apt-get install openjdk-7-jdk maven
JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-7-openjdk-amd64/ ./build.sh

It's related to these:

https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/show_bug.cgi?id=100167
http://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=635

Generally looks like some good cleanup.  Do you really have to close the FileOutputStream() if you close the channel returned from getChannel()?

Also, on the pom changes, I noticed it removed a lot of versions, for anything in a sub-module without a version, is it essentially going to be pulling in the version based on what is defined in the parent pom?

I'm also a little scared that we're going to get into import reordering wars between IntelliJ and Eclipse ;).

Thanks for the merge, and sorry for the belated reply to your comment.

Per http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/io/FileOutputStream.html#close(), closing a FileOutputStream should close any Channels from its getChannel().  I didn't see any documentation about the other way round though, as it was in the code.  It looks like the [OpenJDK7 FileChannelImpl](http://www.docjar.com/html/api/sun/nio/ch/FileChannelImpl.java.html#121) will call close() on the parent stream, but I figured the safest thing was to just call it on both.

Exactly right on the POM changes, I DRY'd up all the versions declared by more than one module to the `<dependencyManagement>` section of the parent POM.  I also added missing declarations to the child POMs for all direct dependencies of each given module.  I'm not sure how much any of these modules will end up as dependencies themselves, but I think it less brittle to declare all direct dependencies rather than counting on transient declarations from upstream.

Regarding the import ordering, I certainly agree with your concern.  I didn't see any IDE metadata, so I wasn't sure what the preferred one was.  My goal was to simply cut down on the volume of trivial Eclipse warnings so that significant ones wouldn't be obscured.  I'll see if Eclipse can't be configured to match IntelliJ's defaults, or just switch to IntelliJ if that's the better option.

Cool.  I took everything but reverted the import stuff in an attempt to mitigate merge conflicts that people might have.  After the fact I realized that I did it wrong (should've pulled your merge into a local repo and revert that one commit before pushing to master) and probably actually created more merge conflicts than would've existed had I kept it.

Anyway, for import optimization, I generally think it's great (and I have IntelliJ configured to optimize things on check-in), but if the only change to a file is import changes and the import isn't currently causing a bug I generally prefer to let it lie.  As far as Eclipse/IntelliJ stuff is concerned, I don't think fighting over ordering is much of a concern as long as we stick to the rule where we only optimize imports if and when we've made some other change to the actual code of a file.  That way, there will be some substance accompanying the import change and we can trust that both IntelliJ and Eclipse know how to include the correct imports no matter how they are ordered.

I will be committing DruidSetup soon which will clean up and improve the setup process (ZkSetup will be labeled as deprecated; the renaming reflects doing more than zookeeper operations.)  DruidSetup will also enable storing Druid ensemble properties in zookeeper to simplify administration.
Fixed in https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/23
If you could fix the dump issue, I'll do the merge.
Can I get some more context on what this pull request is doing?

This allows for the future inclusion of quantiles in the visual histogram return value.  First, the min. and max. values are returned in the quantiles array.

In the future, we might include some streaming quantile estimation algorithm (e.g. when asked for the median, quartiles, deciles, ...) or just add a getQuantiles() method to Histogram objects to approximate the quantiles from the histogram data (not in a streaming fashion).
Pushed latest set of changes according to some of the code review comments.

I want to warn against fixing this by treating missing metadata as an interval that did not contain data, as long as s3 remains a possible storage layer. S3 consistency issues in that case will cause us to miss valid buckets.

Yes, I think the proper mechanism to fix this is to have it use a similar mechanism to how the determine_partitions job communicates back the partitions: it writes to the local working path (hdfs) and the subsequent job reads from there.

Basically, I think the fix is to have the IndexGeneratorJobs write out the descriptor to the working directory as well as the output directory.  The DbUpdaterJob then reads the descriptors from the working directory instead of the output directory.  It will look weird to anybody who only uses HDFS and doesn't care about the eventual consistency of S3, but it's not the end of the world.
This has been rectified to a certain extent.  We still need to add unit tests for GroupBy queries.

It looks like your maven is probably configured to only ever look at your Nexus repo at repo.bazaarvoice.com.  This is something that you can technically change from your settings.xml, but in order to fit within the regulations of your organization, you will probably need to ask whoever administers your nexus repo to proxy the 3rd party repositories that we use:

https://metamx.artifactoryonline.com/metamx/pub-libs-releases-local
https://repository.jboss.org/nexus/content/repositories/thirdparty-uploads

the first one is our own repository and houses our open internal libraries.  The latter we use to pull down sigar (http://support.hyperic.com/display/SIGAR/Home)

I'm working on getting our other libraries mirrored into central so that we can remove the dependence on our own artifactory, but until that is done, you will have to either have your nexus proxy through to these third-party repositories or configure your machine to be able to see the repositories in the base pom.xml.  

If you want to go the route of adjusting your development machine, then the place to check will be settings.xml.  you probably have some <mirrorOf></mirrorOf> properties set with a wildcard or something like that.
Thanks!

Case closed ;)

I greatly simplified the balancing code at the expense of making the unit tests not very meaningful.

The main problem in DruidMasterBalancerTest.java is that the LoadQueuePeons are mocked (I couldn't figure an easy way to put in real objects here).  BalancerCostAnalyzer uses information from the load queues to figure out which segments will be where (not present in the test because it's hard to mock), so it dumps all the segments on the first other server in the list.

Another issue is that we don't have good information in the unit tests.  Before, a lot of the complexity was to keep track of the cost change of given moves.  Outside of a test (e.g. in production), this isn't a problem.  Every time the helper runs, it emits the total cluster cost, so we can just look at those differences.  Is there a way to make the balancer helper run a second time only for the test?
On the question of running the helper multiple times.  You should be able to do that...  I'm not sure I'm fully udnerstanding why you cannot, so let's take that up in a conversation.

This would be nice.  We already run a Ceph cluster, so I am seriously considering putting a Ceph RBD underneath Druid. If there is an advantage to be had by separating the data out into key/vals.  Maybe I can begin work on a libRADOS storage mechanism.
Duplicated by https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/67

I'll go back later in the week and make the Javadoc stuff nicer.

I decided that it probably wasn't worth the trouble running the helper a second time.

The last move ([1] to [2]) is because we're "assuming loads will fail unless they actually succeed", so it thinks that [1] still has 4 segments and prefers to move the last segment to [2].
and it should be "fields not "field" parameter for arithmetic_aggregation
Configuration of the worker nodes and the scaling strategy is now done via a MySQL table. An interface to configure these things do not yet exist.

The linked patch doesn't fix the problem completely, still needs

https://github.com/madvertise/druid/commit/1a0b57a7cda5a41dfdd1b4a0851b0e97dfcffd4f

Directionally, yes, I think this is the direction I was thinking of as well.

As far as who handles the zipping/unzipping.  I was thinking of that as a function of the transfer of the data and not necessarily as something that the system would handle automatically.  One reason is because I've been intending to go back and create the ZipInputStream directly on the InputStream object pulled from S3 so that we can just unzip as we pull and save storing the file twice.  (We do notice some IO contention on AWS nodes when pulling down and then unzipping.  AWS is just bad at IO, so the optimization makes sense, but was never enough of a reason in and of itself to go back and change the code...).  I'd like to think of a way to retain the ability to get this optimization but still simplify the pulling logic.

As for the other formats like gzip and nothing, they are all legacy formats that some of our segments still use, but very few.  Once we get rid of those, we will be able to clean up that part of the cruft in the code.

The MMappedQueryableIndexFactory existed to juxtapose an InMemoryQueryableIndexFactory that used to exist, but let fall to the wayside 'cause mmapped operation has been plenty good for us.  It could probably be removed, but it does serve to hide the static call to IndexIO, which I believe is still meaningful...  That whole interaction breaks the DI model, but it's not gonna go away for a while.  More migratory steps are required to clean that bit up, so I'd prefer to have the abstraction layer in there, even if it is practically meaningless.

Btw, how much time are you getting to spend on this?  Some things have occurred internally that are threatening to bump this up on my own priority list of things to do, so I'd like to coordinate that to make sure all toes are intact.

Thanks for the feedback.  I get you on the compression being a data transfer concern.  Looking into adding an hdfs or even LocalFS puller, it was clear to me that I'd be doing a lot of what was in the S3 and S3Zipped Pullers and it seemed like an opportunity to reduce the duplication by moving some of the concerns.  I was really more interested in moving the local-file-caching logic up, but the compression came with it.  As is, you could still handle your own unzipping, and just return the raw unpacked directory to the loader (so you could do your Zip stream with s3 approach and just return the final unpacked directory)…but if that is an optimization that would be useful more broadly, then my commit doesn't really make it much easier :)

It would be easy enough to add a ZipUtil or even StreamUtil (and that may be the right first step), but it seems like there is another object trying come out.  I was thinking that a SegmentFileCache might make sense or even letting the Segment know about where its files are located.  On Segments knowing the file location, it may not currently fit with Incrementals, but even those could have dirs to flush to and then maybe some of the FireHydrant code could move in?  And Sinks could be a Composite Segments made up of Incrementals?  A bit too foggy for me right now, but thought it worth mentioning.  

With a SegmentFileCache, the Puller would take the segment and the cache as arguments.  The SegmentFileCache might have helper methods like addSegmentDir(ZipInputStream), and addSegmentDir(File).  The former would be useful for folks that just have zipped pushes and can get the zip stream.  The later would be used by implementations that want/need to do their own deflating: oh, I have snappy tars, i need to decompress and unpack them myself, and call addSegmentDir with my unpacked File Dir.  I suppose it could also have an addDir(Iterable<Tuple<String,InputStream>>) where the Tuple key is the file name, and the Stream is the file.  The Iterable impl might be a bit more involved, but would allow for the least IO because the cache would pull all the streams directly to the final destination instead of starting with a tmp dir which might be on a different volume (and if it is going to yet another remote fs, it could just copy from input stream to output stream and save the disk io altogether).

On the index factory, I wasn't really thinking nuke the whole abstraction, but instead work toward having IndexIO implement the QueryableIndexFactory interface itself.  With the internal version  map it really does seem like a factory, and that could start to move IndexIO away from statics.  But I can see leaving the other factory and just mentally putting IndexIO into a static helper boat.  I will say I really don't think 'factorize' is a good name for the method :)

I really tried not to drop a wall of text here.  In the end, I'd like to be able have Druid indices stored/loaded from HDFS and a "local" File System (where it may be actually pulling from a network drive, which is another reason I think the segment file cache makes sense, because it could ensure the files are pulled to local disk no matter what the remote store is).  I know enough now that I think I could do the pullers without these changes.  I'm happy to just let this be ideas to chew on as you tackle improving the segment store stuff.
This was introduced by the update to the newest version of Jackson.  It has been fixed in master, so I'm closing.  Please re-submit if this is still happening.

This is a limitation of Java...

http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4724038

We can apparently do something similar to 

 https://github.com/dain/leveldb/blob/master/leveldb/src/main/java/org/iq80/leveldb/util/ByteBufferSupport.java

In order to work around it, which should be fine.  We have to make sure that we never reference those buffers any more, but that should be pretty easy.
This should be fixed in Master.  Closing
Fixed.

Fwiw, those handles are given up on GC, so your systems probably aren't doing old generation GC often enough just yet.  If you increase load (or decrease the size of your java heap), this will become a non issue.

We see this sometimes on some of our less used test/demo environments, but have never seen it on prod, for example.
This is done.

Sixtus, most of the query load that we see on our cluster finish before a status page would end up loading.

Instead of having a status page like this, we have opted for emitting metrics on every request and then using an external tool (for us, it actually gets piped back into Druid and visualized with our dashboard...) to monitor the query volumes.

Took the jar out of the main directory. That's only useful when one is building something as a framework that is co-located with an app. I added the license but still need to add some docs/readme.

Can you agree to one of the CLAs as they exist in the current repository?  Our CLAs are based on the Apache CLA.

If you are operating as an individual, you can just agree to the Individual CLA, you can simple reply with a comment stating, "I agree to the DruidIndividualCLA as it exists in the master branch of http://www.github.com/metamx/druid on _date_".

If the corporate CLA is the proper CLA for your work, then you can do it with a comment if you also add a statement that "I represent that, as _my title_, I have sufficient authority to agree to this CLA on behalf of _my organization_."  You might also prefer to give the documents to your legal team and have them deliver them to us.
